column4: You could probably do a minimal install and then use dselect.
Sounds like maybe tasksel is the modern equivalent.
I haven't used anything like that in a long time, but I remember installing Debian and choose which software I wanted with dselect.
I just installed opensuse the other day, and it supports choosing packages to install. So i'd really like ubuntu to have this feature.
I'm checking Tasksel out.
Remember Ubuntu is pretty closely focused around ease of use, so I wouldn't hold my breath if I were you.

It's just not a feature that is probably widely desired.  If that's up your alley,  would suspect Debian might suit you better.  To a large degree there's not that huge a difference between Ubuntu and Debian.
Personally, I just figure the normal install is mostly stuff I want, and then I can always apt-get remove stuff I don't want.
OK, may be I should install Debian. but can I add ppa source to Debian?
You've got me.  I really haven't used Debian since before Ubuntu existed.
You probably can't use the Ubuntu ones with Debian (or well, maybe you can but it's probably asking for conflicts).  But there may be equivalent stuff for Debian.
It's OK. I will find that out myself. Thanks for your help.
Right.  Certainly you could ask around in #debian

two more quick question: does apt-get remove completely removes everything relates to that package? will it leave garbages? and how do I find all packages used by a certain piece of software? I tried to remove all packages contains phrase "evolution" and I was prompted that gnome-desktop would be removed too.
apt-get remove will not remove some files, containing settings and things I think.  But apt-get purge will
In the info for a package you can see which packages are dependent on that package.
You can definitely see that in Synaptic.
gnome-desktop may just be a meta-package.
Meaning it may not actually install anything, it's just a placeholder that depends on a bunch of other things.  So that by installing that you'll install all those things at once.
Thanks, I didn't check package dependence. Will do that in the future.
It should say in the package description if it's just a meta-package.
